title: noel edmonds rachel riley lloyds advert sued bank
story: The Countdown star, 32, appeared in the ad alongside a host of other stars encouraging people to speak up about their mental health.Noel, 69, who is locked in a legal battle with the bank over a fraud case, launched an attack against her because she is part of the banks propaganda, The Mail reports.The Deal or No Deal host also demanded Rachel hand back the money and restore your integrity.But she has lashed out at the presenter on Twitter - claiming she didnt make any money from appearing in the advert.She said: I’m proud to have taken part in a diversity in advertising campaign with @channel4 &amp @AskLloydsBank to encourage conversations in mental health issues.For my involvement, a total of £8K was donated to my favourite charity @wwwalmtorg. I personally didn’t receive a penny. She continued: I have supported &amp will continue to support MH campaigns I believe in. The response I received to this campaign’s “get it out in the open” messaging was overwhelmingly positive from people affected by these issues &amp shows just how important discussing mental health issues is.Noel claimed Rachel had been paid £20,000 to appear in the campaign as he urged Rachel to undo the damage.He said: It’s possible that Rachel is not aware that Lloyds Bank is responsible for the destruction of lives and livelihoods on a military scale.You’re either with the victims or the perpetrators.The advert campaign, which is partnered with Mental Health UK, sees Rachel encouraging people to open up about their demons while wearing a Post-it note saying: #gettheinsideout.Noel is currently suing Lloyds for £60million over a fraud ten years ago that he claims crippled his TV business.He said his former entertainment business Unique Group was ruined by corrupt financiers at HBOS in Reading, which was later bought by Lloyds.Crooked financiers from the firm were caged last year for the £245 million loans scam, which they squandered on prostitutes and luxury holidays.Noel took an overdose in 2005 after “losing everything” to the swindlers.He has also taken his compensation fight against Lloyds to the airwaves – creating his own station to bash the bankers.Lloyds has said it made determined efforts to reach a consensual resolution with Noel last year but this was not possible.A spokesman said: As a formal litigation process has begun it would be inappropriate to comment other than to say his claim will be contested.

title: labour shadow sports minister says brexit has made england flag synonymous with far right and racism
story: The astonishing statement from Rosena Allin-Khan came despite millions of fans proudly displaying the St Georges cross during the World Cup.The shadow sports minister has launched a campaign to reclaim the flag, claiming its been hijacked by racists.She added that after Brexit, people dont like flying the flag because its not welcoming to minorities.Ms Allin-Khan told The House magazine: I do feel this time, particularly given how well we did, there was a significant lack of St George’s crosses.I think that many people feel that flying a St George’s cross is synonymous with far-right ideology and that sometimes prevents them from doing so because they don’t want to be perceived as such.“During previous World Cups between 2000-2010 you could walk 20 metres and see flags in windows, flags on cars, flags on shops. Despite more sprouting up as the tournament went on, there’s been a noticeable difference.I think there is a reluctance to do so because shops may not want to feel they’re not being welcoming to members of the community, and perhaps Brexit has a part to play in that.Senior Labour figures have previously got in trouble for mocking the England flag.Emily Thornberry, one of Jeremy Corbyns closest allies, was forced to quit Ed Milibands Shadow Cabinet after posting a photo of a house in Rochester with St Georges flags flying outside.

title: caravan bluebird penthouse high bickington devon taw valley
story: The gleaming cabin complete with kitchen, bath and a wine cellar is a far cry from the abandoned wreck Ralph Westmacott stumbled upon three years ago.After discovering it on his father-in-laws farm in Devon, the innovater decided to give the old Bluebird a new lease of life and spent 2,000 man hours and several thousand pounds on turning it into a quirky holiday home with a 1950s theme.He sourced a vintage green and white kitchenette and other period decor to transform it into a charming bolthole that takes guests back to the halcyon days of post-war Hi-de-Hi-style holidays.It comes with a double bed, a bathroom and central heating that is powered by a biomass boiler.The walls are painted white and green, and the floor has a checked pattern in the same two colours.Outside is a unique hot tub that is set in the chassis of an old Land Rover.The caravan, called the Bluebird Penthouse, is located on Ralphs father-in-laws farm at High Bickington in north Devon which has stunning views over the Taw Valley.The incredible transformation cost Ralph several thousand pounds but he is now recouping the investment as the caravan is fully booked for the rest of the summer at £130 a night.There is also a service fee of £49, which goes towards covering cleaning costs in preparation for the next guests.Ralph said he and his wife Lucy are delighted with how business is going, even if it means they cant stay in the caravan themselves.He said: The whole idea started when my father-in-law was talking about scrapping an old caravan that had been wasting away on his farm.I thought it seemed pretty cool and eventually managed to convince him to allow me to restore it.It was a lot of work and I lost count of how many hours I put into it somewhere around the 2,000 hour stage.The hot tub was similar really, it was an old farm Land Rover that had not been used for years and was just rusting away.With a bit of clever design we managed to use it as the foundation for a hot tub, which has turned out to be an incredibly popular feature.We consciously didnt do too much work to the exterior, because the ever so slightly tired look helps it to blend into the hillside.Its taken off hugely this year, just getting bigger and bigger and were all delighted with how its going.

title: yellowstone park state emergency supervolcano erupt latest
story: In this terrifying video, a huge, steam-spewing fissure is visible on a volcano in Grand Teton National Park in Wyoming, near inspiration point and hidden falls.Park officials have since closed off two areas of the park, citing concern for peoples safety.The National Park Service said that its possible the crack could have been caused by regular seismic activity, but they arent sure of the exact causes and have launched an investigation.Superintendent David Vela said: Human safety is our number one priority, and with an abundance of caution we are temporarily closing this area until we can properly asses the situation.Rangers have not confirmed when the areas with reopen, but they are currently completing a risk assessment.Grand Teton National Park is around seven miles away from Yellowstone National Park and the Yellowstone supervolcano.If both volcanoes were to erupt, it could cause a massive explosion capable of wiping of millions of people.Earlier this year and abnormal river of lava was found underneath the Yellowstone supervolcano - experts said if it were to erupt, the river could cause a mega eruption with the potential to wipe out western America.Last year a swarm of 1,400 mini earthquakes took place at the National Park, terrifying experts.

title: diana would have known how to fix the meghan and thomas markle debacle
story: So many people have ­commented on the likeness between the late Princess Diana and Charlotte, the granddaughter she sadly never met.Diana often spoke of her desire for a daughter and she would have doted on Princess Charlotte.I can imagine proud Granny taking her to Disneyland and buying Princess outfits. She would have let Charlotte run riot in her bedroom, trying on all her designer clothes and shoes and raiding her make-up bag.It’s so tragic that all of these happy times were not to be. When William saw all of his children come into the world, most especially baby Charlotte, he must have felt the loss of his mother even more keenly.Diana would have been there with her arms full of presents, and not just for the babies. There would have been thoughtful gifts for Kate and lots of hugs and happy tears.You can well picture her ­giving newlywed Harry a cheeky nudge and telling him to “get on with it” so she could have more grandchildren to spoil.I also think that if Diana had still been alive this sad situation between Meghan Markle and her dad would never have been allowed to turn so toxic.Diana would have seen this potential problem looming even before the engagement was announced and nipped it firmly in the bud.She would have insisted and ensured he was invited to the UK and would have dispensed shrewd and invaluable advice on how to deal with all of the hoopla surrounding the wedding. Diana learned the hard way how to deal with the media and palace officials. She was misquoted, manipulated and misunderstood during her time as a royal wife and knew all the pitfalls and how to avoid them.Skittish Meghan would have been soothed and calmed and all of the bad feeling among the Markle family would have surely evaporated.Diana would have advised Meghan’s dad on his wedding suit, helped him with his speech and rehearsed him walking down the aisle.She would have put this rather shy and ordinary man completely at ease.Rather than watching his daughter getting married on TV while cowering in a cheap bed and breakfast in the US, he would have been an integral part of the happiest day of her life.Instead, we have a constant stream of ill-advised interviews given by Thomas where he appears to have been ignored and abandoned and, whether it’s fair or not, Meghan seems increasingly cold-hearted.Photos yesterday of. him celebrating his 74th birthday alone with just a fast food takeaway for company don’t exactly help, whether they were staged again or not.A present, phone call or card from Meghan would have gone a long way to build bridges.It’s all turning a tawdry soap opera meaning commentators such as Sharon Osbourne will keep the pot boiling.Just this week she inferred Thomas has a drink problem and should get clean, ensuring more lurid headlines and bad feeling as he furiously has to deny all of the allegations.No one is coming out of this well and never has Princess Diana been more missed.Harry needs her wise counsel and William knows what an important part she could have played in the lives of his ­children.I know her sons will never really get over her death, but I do hope when William looks into his daughter’s beautiful eyes he is heartened to see a reflection of his mum rather than finding it ­unbearably sad.THE way BBC News treated Cliff Richard was utterly shameful and I’m not in the least surprised it lost its court case.The poor man went through years of hell and became a virtual recluse – and his physical and mental health was profoundly affected.At a time when he should have been enjoying the rewards of a lifetime’s graft, he was enduring sleepless nights and often crying in anguish on the kitchen floor.Many in the media have expressed fear and disquiet that any sort of Cliff’s Law will mean restrictions on newspapers, radio and TV, and this is indeed troubling.But the blame should be pointed firmly at those who thought it was a good idea to send a helicopter to film and report an OTT police raid on an innocent man.Seeing Cliff outside the courtroom this week looking extremely fragile and on the verge of tears was heartbreaking.Clearly the sunny, friendly, optimistic Peter Pan of Pop has gone for good and in his place is a haggard, careworn, wary victim.Before the court case, Cliff told me he doesn’t have photos taken with fans and their children any more.It was painful to see the hurt and mistrust in his eyes.He then revealed this week that his VIP status meant he was allowed to use the secret Wimbledon tunnel under Centre Court and Court No1 to bounce quickly between both venues and view as much tennis as possible.Cliff doesn’t do that any more, and never will, because the tunnel goes past the ball boys’ changing area and he doesn’t want to put himself in a situation where he could potentially be accused of something unspeakable.I really hope that when enough time has passed he can get some of that old “glass half full” spirit back, but he will never be the person he was.And no one else should have to go through such a hideous ordeal when they have done nothing wrong.IF you don’t want to watch a movie that will make you laugh, cry and come out singing Abba songs, we can’t be friends.I thoroughly enjoyed Mamma Mia! Here We Go Again – a rare example of a sequel that is better than the original.The starry cast includes Meryl Streep, Julie Walters, PIerce Brosnan, Andy Garcia and Colin Firth. But the cherry on the icing on the cheesecake is the legend that is Cher.I was lucky enough to host the world premiere this week in London and had the chance to talk to the cast, who were effusive in their praise of Her Cherness.It was surprising to hear she STILL gets nervous before going on set and she was genuinely bewildered by all the love in the air for her.I thought one elderly gay gentleman was going to explode with happiness when Cher blew him a kiss.It was so endearing – and there is nothing more deliciously camp than Cher stepping out of a helicopter in a blonde wig and sequins before going on to sing Super Trouper. She’s a class act and a throughly lovely woman.WATCHING politicians squabble like ferrets in a sack soon loses its novelty value – and our eyes are now glazing over whenever the dreaded subject of Brexit rears its ugly head.But we should never forget that when we woke up the day after the referendum – to discover a majority had voted to leave the EU – there was NO actual plan.Bupkis. Nada. Zilch. Diddly-squat.There wasn’t even a “to do” list.Instead, all the rats deserted the sinking ship, claiming the dog had eaten their homework or a big boy did it and ran away – leaving the (female) PM to tidy up their reeking mess. Funny that.No matter which way you voted, surely we can all agree on one thing.There was little or no thought put into how to actually implement such a seismic change. Not even a few notes on the back of a fag packet.Now, two years down the line, the whole big, fat mess is farcical and beyond parody.As a nation, we are a laughing stock.Shame on all those careerists and fence-sitters for their arrogance, stupidity and downright mendacity in not having even a half-arsed plan in place.A parcel of rogues, right enough.IF you fancy a right good laugh at some silly, bonkers, hilarious fun and games, tune in to BBC1 today at 5.05pm for another helping of Wedding Day Winners with myself and Rob Beckett.One couple will actually get married at the end of the show and it’s all very lighthearted and joyful.DID Burberry REALLY need to make a bonfire of its overpriced designer swag and burn an eye-watering £28million worth of clothing and cosmetics?In line with other designer labels, the fashion house claims the move was to stop counterfeiters getting their hands on garments and using them to produce fakes.But surely that just doesn’t add up.If criminals want to reproduce any designer clothes or handbags, they can go into any shop and purchase something – or, even simpler, just order it online.Could Burberry not instead have the mother of all sales in aid of Help for Heroes, or for the homeless charity Centrepoint, or any number of deserving causes here and in the Third World?That £28million would have gone a hell of a long way to help those in need.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: proud mum claims her baby spoke his first words at nine weeks
story: She was stunned when she said “hiya” and “love you” to little Tommy-Frank and he repeated the words back.Sara, 29, said: “At first I thought I was going mad but he said it a few times. We caught it on video — it’s as plain as day.”Tommy-Frank was born in mid-April and by mid-June his gurgling started to sound like words.Sara, from Newcastle, who also has an eight-year-old daughter Eva-Jane, said: “I was speaking to him and he was copying what I was saying.“At first I thought is he really saying it or is it just sounds? But then he said, ‘I love you’.“At one stage my daughter was playing with him on the sofa and she was saying “love you, love you” and he said it back to her and we were like ‘wow’.“People thought I was making it up until they heard the video.”Most babies begin to talk at about 18 months, saying simple words.Care assistant Sara added: “I can’t remember how old Eva-Jane was when she started talking, but it was nowhere near as young as Tommy-Frank.“I know there won’t be an official record of the world’s youngest talking baby but I reckon Tommy-Frank is there or thereabouts.“Perhaps he will grow up to be a genius.”HAVE you got a miracle baby? title: yvette cooper marry ed balls mp strictly
story: Heres what we know about the female politician.Senior Labour party politician Yvette, 49, married Ed Balls on January 10 1998 in Eastbourne.The wedding was attended by the cream of new Labours political and media set, with reports of who was talking to whom being phoned to tony Blairs aides, who were in Tokyo at the time, the New Statesman reported.Yvette and Ed and have three children together - daughters Ellie and Maddy, and a son called Joel.They were the first married couple to serve together in the British cabinet.Yvette has been an MP since 1997, serving for Normanton, Pontefract and Castleford.She served in the cabinet between 2008 and 2010 a chief secretary to the Treasury before serving as Secretary of State for Work and Pensions.when Labour lost the 2010 general election, Yvette was appointed Shadow Foreign Secretary.She became Shadow Home Secretary a year later.In May 2015, Yvette announced she would run to be leader of the Labour party after Ed Milliband resigned.Yvette came third with 17 per cent of the vote in the first round.In 2016, Ed took part in BBCs strictly Come Dancing - partnered with Russian dancer Katya Jones.But while the former politician was a huge hit with fans on the show, Yvette said her husbands commitment to the competition affected their home life.during an interview with Good Morning Britain at the time, she said: Early on he was doing a lot of practising in the kitchen.But the trouble is now that the dances have got wilder and wilder, he just bumps into the kitchen cooker, so it doesnt work.Yvette also suggested husbands newfound passion for dance was part of a midlife crisis.Speaking at the launch of his book, Speaking Out, in September 2016, she said: Be it the marathons, the football club, or the early morning piano practice, and now the dancing, the family have now go to the point of thinking: do you know what, Ed, just get on with it and buy the sodding motorbike.  Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: tinned food sales are up
story: Sales have risen for the first time in five years, up 2.7 per cent to £2.3billion last year.That’s three billion cans based on a typical selling price of 75p.Staples such as baked beans and soups had fallen in popularity as people tried healthier options.But The Grocer mag said: “Part of the can’s revival is down to growing concern over the economy and Brexit. With food and drink prices rising across the board consumers are turning to tinned food as a means of saving money.”Middle-class shoppers moving to budget stores like Aldi pushed up the number of units sold.Baked beans - £353m (up2.5%)Soup - £327m (up 2.2%)Tomato products - £248m (up 3.9%)Fruit - £165m (up 3.9%)Sales revenue also rose as some products became pricier. Fish, the biggest sector in canned foods, saw a 4.5 per cent rise in spending to £516million.This was due to the price of salmon and tuna going up by as much as 11 per cent as the Pound falls in value.Baked bean sales rose by 2.5 per cent to £353million. Soup rose 2.2 per cent to £327million and tinned tomatoes 3.9 per cent to £248million.Rice pud and fruit are also back on our shelves, say experts Kantar.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: head teachers fun day ban for children absent just once in a year
story: Children as young as four have also been blacklisted after their parents kept them at home for only a single day through illness.It means just 29 of the 420 pupils at Maypole Primary School in Dartford, Kent, will be invited to the sports, arts and crafts event on Monday.Parents blasted the barmy ruling yesterday and claimed it punished children for things outside their control.Single dad Tommy Lynch, 38, said he kept his children, aged six and nine, at home on the anniversary of their mum’s death.The builder said: “I was fined for taking them away on the day and I’m happy to be punished for that because I’m an adult — but why punish the kids?”He added: “Even if the kids are minutes late it’s marked as an absence.”Lucy Cox said her son missed one day when she kept him at home with conjunctivitis for which he needed regular drops.She said: “If I’d sent him in, as advised, all the children and teachers would have had it within days. I am a teacher and value education, but this reward system helps no one.“One hundred per cent attendance is down to good luck or irresponsible parenting, neither of which seems right to reward. It shocks me it’s still allowed.“Children as young as four are being discriminated against.”Head Linda Wilmann said: “We’ve always had an annual award for those pupils who achieve 100 per cent attendance for the whole year. It’s a massive achievement and should be recognised.“Attendance and punctuality are crucial to ensure children get the most from their time at school.”Earlier this month two schools left devastated students sobbing when they refused to give them ice creams because of their bad attendance.GOT a story? title: jeremy corbyns strategists in private bust up over confusing brexit policy
story: Shadow International Trade Secretary Barry Gardiner complained in a meeting of Jeremy Corbyn’s shadow cabinet that the party’s Brexit policy was too complicated to explain in the media.He told the private meeting it was “really hard” to explain Labour’s ‘six tests’ on Brexit - which were set out by Shadow Brexit Secretary Sir Keir Starmer as a way to decide whether to back the Government’s final EU deal.Mr Gardiner was famously overheard calling the six tests “b*****ks” earlier this year.His outburst at the meeting last week sparked a furious reaction from Shadow Brexit Secretary Sir Keir Starmer.He shot back: “It’s also hard doing any media when your colleagues are caught calling it b*****ks.”The pair have clashed on a number of occasions since joining the shadow cabinet - despite both being key figures in drawing up Labour’s Brexit policy.Last summer Mr Gardiner said being in a customs union with the EU would be “deeply unattractive” - only for Sir Keir to make it party policy six months later.And Sir Keir publicly rebuked Mr Gardiner after he described the Good Friday Agreement as outdated earlier this year.Shadow Cabinet sources refused to comment on the latest clash. One said: “We don’t comment on private meetings.”  Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: top government brexit negotiator receives a 20000 performance related bonus
story: Mark Bowman’s bumper salary top up emerged just a day after a similar lump sum was announced for Theresa May’s Brexit guru Olly Robbins.Mr Bowman heads up EU relations in the Treasury and received the largest bonus of any official in the beancounting department.He was central to negotiations with Brussels over the so called “divorce bill” that will see the UK continuing to pay billions to the EU in spending promises made before the referendum.Last night Government insiders defended the “performance-related bonus”, saying the EU had demanded much more cash but Mr Bowman had played hardball during testy exit talks late last year.A Whitehall source said: “Mark Bowman saved the UK taxpayer £60 billion in December, after the EU demanded £100 billion, he’d be cheap at twice the price.”GOT a story? title: dog trapped hot car owners shocking response
story: The disturbing images show the poor pooch collapsed on the ground sweltering in the heat in Swindon, Wilts, on Thursday.A parking ticket on the car led those who discovered the animal to believe that it had been there for at least 120 minutes.According to witnesses, when the owners did turn up they reportedly gave false information to the police and didnt see what the issue was.Temperatures inside a locked car can soar to almost double in a matter of hours, and can be lethal to dogs.Samantha Claire Hardwidge stumbled upon the boiling husky with a fellow colleague and shared the pictures online.She wrote on Facebook: “Shout out to the owners of this car who felt it appropriate to leave their husky in their car.The parking ticket shows them arriving at 10.47am. The dog was found by me and my colleague in a poor state at 12.35pm - with the parking ticket showing they could park until 1.46pm.The police were called and removed the dog from the car. The owners arrived back at the car and proceeded to shout and swear that they didn’t see what the problem is.The owners refused to take the dog to the vets to be checked despite it being visibly distressed from being in the car for so long.The owners refused to pass their details to the police and eventually gave false information.The dog was seized so it could be checked by a vet.”The photographs show the distressed husky inside the car, and later lying on the ground on its side with a water bowl beside it.The post has received more than 15,000 shares and nearly 5,000 comments from furious social media users.Kay Sell said: “Disgusting, the owners should be locked in the car for several hours and then go to jail if they are still alive.”Susan Barker said: “Bad enough to lock any creature in a car with this heat, let alone a husky type with their thick underfur. Morons.”Ted Davis added: Stupid is not what I would say, so cruel. Idiots.While Valerie Lorne said simply: “Disgusting behaviour.”A spokeswoman from Wiltshire Police said: “When we arrived the dog was heavily panting and not responding.“The window was slightly open but the dog was obviously in distress.“We managed to get the dog out and a kind member of the public got the dog some fresh water. Fortunately, the dog perked up.“The owners arrived and we ensured that the dog was taken to a local vets for a check-up.”Temperatures in Swindon reached a high of 29 degrees yesterday, but temperatures inside the car would have been much higher.A Wiltshire Police spokesman added today: It is not advisable to leave any animal locked in a car during warm weather, a car can become as hot as an oven very quickly, even when it doesnt feel that warm outside.The RSPCA estimates that in 22 degree weather, a car can reach an unbearable 47 degrees within an hour.If you come across a dog in a car during warm weather, and youre concerned that the dog appears uncomfortable you should call police on 101 to report it.If the dog is in clear distress then call us on 999.No arrests have been made, but police said their enquiries were ongoing.

title: philip hammond brexit betrayal eu borders
story: The Chancellor was at the centre of a row during the Prime Minister’s Chequers summit two weeks ago after appearing to suggest Britain’s borders should be on the Brussels negotiation table.He angered colleagues including Home Secretary Sajid Javid by insisting Britain needed to be given “maximum flexibility to negotiate.”Minutes from the Chequers summit stated that Mr Hammond argued in favour of offering preferential treatment to EU workers in a bid to win the backing of German Chancellor Angela Merkel.He urged Cabinet colleagues to keep options open for preferential mobility arrangements for EU citizens.But Mr Javid and Defence Secretary Gavin Williamson said any perception that free movement was continuing would be toxic to voters.Mr Javid insisted “free movement had to end”, adding that there must be “no back door” for EU nationals after Brexit.The pro-EU Chancellor has been one of the biggest advocates for softer Brexit around the Cabinet table - to the fury of Leave supporting Tory MPs.But his allies insisted that he does not want to keep free movement for EU citizens to come to the UK forever - but was raising concerns about labour mobility after Brexit.Details of the tense standoff during the Brexit showdown at the PM’s country house are revealed today by Sun columnist James Forsyth.But sources close to Theresa May have insisted that that there is “no room in the PM’s mind for one iota of deviation on free movement.”They say: “If you can’t say free movement has ended, you can’t have a deal that’s sellable in any way.According to minutes seen by the Daily , he said: Such an agreement would be very important for the Chancellor of Germany.If the UK sought her help to deliver this deal, it would need to be prepared to negotiate on this point.But Mr Javid hit back by saying free movement had to end, insisting there must be no back door for EU nationals after Brexit.The minutes stated that the Chancellor disagreed with the Home Secretary on labour mobility and ending free movement.Revelations that Mr Hammond wants to put free movement on the negotiating table is likely to open up another explosive row with Tory Brexiteers.Our revelation comes as Mrs May faced fresh pressure to rule out giving any further concessions to Brussels as negotiations come to a head in the Autumn.Brexiteer Commons Leader Andrea Leadsom publicly warned that the Chequers plan must be the final offer rather than an opening gambit.But Mrs May risked fresh wrath from her MPs by refusing to explicitly rule out further concessions to Brussels.Asked if Mrs Leadsom was correct to describe the Chequers agreement as Britains final offer to the EU, a spokesman for the PM would only say: The proposals that we put forward in the White Paper are what we believe to be the only credible and realistic way to move the negotiations forward and that was made clear numerous times by the PM.”Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt sparked further fears by twice refusing to describe Chequers as the “final offer”.He would only say: “It’s our substantive offer I think is the best way to phrase it,” during a visit to Scotland. Our journalists title: worlds first test tube baby leaves flowers on grave of forgotten ivf pioneer who helped create her
story: Louise Brown, 39, was born at Oldham General Hospital on July 25, 1978 after her parents Lesley and John became the first people to successfully undergo in vitro fertilisation.Her birth attracted controversy, with religious leaders expressing concern about the use of artificial intervention and some raising fears that science was creating Frankenbabies, but also paved the way for around eight million IVF births across the world to date.Louise, now a mother-of-two living in Bristol with her husband, Wesley Mullinder, said that the contribution of embryologist Jean Purdy deserved greater recognition, alongside the better-known involvement of gynaecologist Patrick Steptoe and physiologist Robert Edwards.Purdy, who was initially hired as a lab technician by Edwards, was the first person to witness the successful cell division of the embryo that would become Louise.She co-authored 26 academic papers about IVF and helped found the Bourn Hall fertility clinic in Cambridgeshire, but is rarely mentioned in the story of IVF.Purdy died in 1985, aged 39.Louise, who works as a clerk at a freight company, said: Jean Purdy was, I was told by my mum, the one who saw all the cells dividing which is now me. Without her I dont think IVF would have taken off.I know Bob and Patrick used to go home to their wives and families and I think it was Jean that used to stay and make sure everything was just as it should have been.She described them as three great people and said she hopes Purdy gets the recognition she deserves now.She was speaking at Bourn Hall to mark 40 years of IVF, and earlier laid flowers at Purdys new memorial at the Church of St Andrew and St Mary in Grantchester where she is buried.Steptoe died in 1988 aged 74, and Edwards died in 2013 aged 87.Edwards, who was awarded the Nobel Prize in 2010 for the development of IVF, had previously said there were three original pioneers in IVF not just two.She said her parents received weird mail over the years, including a package from California containing a broken test tube with a foetus and fake blood, but that she had never had any nasty approaches and definitely not recently.

title: jacob rees mogg says brussels chiefs are acting like the mafia this is why
story: The Brexit ringleader hit out out at the EU chief negotiator Michel Barnier’s grumpy press conference saying it showed “why we are right to be leaving the mafia-like European Union.Italian Mafia crime families are famed for their organised protection racketeering - with the comparison likely to incense Eurocrats.The arch-Leaver later explained to The Sun that the “the EU seems to behave like the Mafia so that if you want to leave it then retaliates by behaving unreasonably even at cost to itself.”He added: “Who would want to belong to such an organisation?”Mr Rees-Mogg also took aim on Twitter at gobby Irish premier Leo Varadkar’s “aggressive” claims he would block Irish airspace to British planes if Brexit talks collapsed.However last night prominent Tory Remainer Anna Soubry let rip at Mr Rees-Mogg claiming he was a “force of darkness.”Reigniting bitter public sniping between the Tory factions, the ex-Minister said Jacob Rees Mogg and his Brexiteer colleagues in her own party were “now running Theresa.”She raged: “Since the referendum, the forces of darkness have taken over and they have continued to take over and this week if there was every any doubt who was running this government it was quashed.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: denis thatcher questioned sir paul mccartneys invitation to no10 thank you bash from maggie
story: The Beatles legend was on a list of celebs invited as part of a 1988 “thank you” following a rally during the ex-PM’s election campaign.But husband Sir Denis vetted the guest list and added question marks beside the names of those he said “do not help”.Guests he approved of received red ticks — in­cl­u­ding golfer Nick Faldo and Rolf Harris. His ac­t­i­ons emerged in newly-released documents.They also show that No10 got so many req­uests to loan Lady Thatcher’s toy bears Mrs Teddy and Humphrey for public events staff finally had to refuse.Mrs T’s 1988 anti-European Bruges speech was inspired by a Europhile, files suggest.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: steve mogford united utilities yacht salary
story: United Utilities CEO Steve Mogford has trousered £12m in just five years - despite his company wasting 439 MILLION litres of water a day from leaky pipes.The Daily Mail reports Mr Mogford, 63, owns the 80ft Sea Samphire, air-conditioned throughout and docked in a picturesque marina in Menorca.He is also said to own a luxury villa on the island.The lavish boat comes with a bar, a barbecue, a dining room, and even a jet ski.The custom boat is decked out in teak furniture and has flat-screen TVs in every room.Its brochure boasts: It offers custom-made, spacious entertaining and ensures all your needs are catered for – from dining alfresco while the crew takes the helm, to sipping champagne on the huge flybridge or sleeping soundly between the finest bedlinen in the quietest of cabins.Bury North Labour MP James Frith raged: His customers would be dismayed to learn he has such a high pay packet through which he can afford to own a yacht.Manchester Central Labour MP Lucy Powell added that it was a particularly galling example of excess in utility companies.She added: Constituents would be appalled to learn that, at a utility company which really should be a public asset, executives are paid so much they can afford to lead this kind of lifestyle.

title: arts boss sorry for dyslexic welsh joke
story: Dr Giles Shilson posted his quip under a photo of Cardiff Central railway station departure board which includes stops at Ynys y Barri and Llundain.He wrote: “This must be what it feels like to be dyslexic.”Plaid Cymru’s Leanne Wood said the tweet showed “ignorance and a lack of culture”. She added: “If it was meant to be a joke, it just isn’t funny.”Ynyr Jones added: “If he’d aimed that kind of insult towards any other language he’d be labelled a racist and discriminatory of dyslexia. Why do we accept it?”But some said the post was funny and people needed to “lighten up”.Oxford-educated Dr Shilson, chairman of The Barbican Centre in London, pulled the post and said: “I’d like to apologise. I sent a very thoughtless tweet and unintentionally upset lots of you.“I’m so sorry. It wasn’t my intention to be insulting and I should have realised that it would be.”He added: “I fully appreciate that I should not have sent the tweet in the first place.”Dyslexia is classed as a learning difficuly rather than a learning disability, as sufferers intelligence is not affected.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
